awd_titl_txt: CI-New: Collaborative Research: Developing an Open Networked Airborne Computing Platform
awd_abstract_narration:
Networked airborne computing is a novel computing paradigm that can benefit many important civilian applications, including intelligent transportation, emergency response, infrastructure monitoring, precision agriculture, etc. Networked airborne computing also opens up many new fundamental research opportunities. Despite its importance, existing infrastructures for Unmanned Airborne Systems (UAS) research cannot serve the research needs because they are often designed specifically for a single purpose and/or oriented to missions that involve a single aircraft. Therefore, an open networked airborne computing infrastructure is critically needed to enable the Computer and Information Science and Engineering (CISE) communities and beyond to participate in new research and development in this burgeoning field. This project is expected to produce broad impact related to cooperative multi-UAS applications in emergency, energy, environment, and transportation sectors. This project also provides Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics learning opportunities, and expands underrepresented minority participation. Three of the participating universities are minority-serving and/or Hispanic serving institutions with a large number of underrepresented minority students. 

The objective of this project is to develop a new community infrastructure to enable advanced research on networked airborne computing systems. Specifically, the proposed community infrastructure will provide hardware/software designs and development tools, workshop and training opportunities, and field-test support in a Federal Aviation Administration-designated test site. The proposed airborne computing platform is innovative in that it includes a UAS-mounted generic and interactive computing system, a broadband wireless communication system, a UAS/antenna cooperative control system, and up-to-down application development capabilities to support a full-scale development. Both hardware and software are open-sourced and designed in modules with virtualization support so that CISE researchers can easily enhance or replace modules and instantiate additional virtualized functions to facilitate various research and development activities for networked airborne computing applications and services. The modular design, flexibility and extensibility for new development allow researchers to easily isolate and develop specific components of their own research focus while relying on the basic functionality of other components, thus saving significant cost and time for learning and development. The project opens up opportunities for CISE researchers to quickly develop and test solutions that address many new fundamental challenges in networked airborne computing, and to significantly advance cross-cutting research and development in computing, communication, control, and aerospace.

por.por_cntn:
This collaborative project (1730675, 1953048, 1730570, 1730325) aimed to develop a new community infrastructure to enable advanced research on networked airborne computing systems. Motivated by the gap that existing infrastructures for unmanned aerial system/vehicle (UAS/UAV) research are often designed specifically for a single purpose and oriented to missions that involve a single UAS, the proposed airborne computing platform is innovative in that it includes a UAS-carried generic computing system, a broadband wireless communication system, and a full UAS/antenna cooperative control system to support a full-scale development. Over the project span (09/01/2017 - 08/31/2022), the PIs have achieved significant results in the infrastructure design and development, conducted major efforts in supporting the community, and also participated in many outreach activities that led to broader impacts.

The intellectual merits of the project are summarized as follows. The developed networked airborne computing system features an integrated software and hardware design. The system is composed of six hardware (HW) modules, including Airframe module (HM1), Power source and distribution module (HM2), Directional Antenna (HM3), Flight Controller (HM4), Wi-Fi Router (HM5), and Single board computing module (HM6). The six HW modules support the quadcopter unit, the control unit, the communication and networking unit, and also the computing and storage unit. To enhance the programmability and flexibility of the computing platform, we first explored virtualization techniques such as virtual machines and containers. Then, to further achieve robust networked airborne computing, we developed a suite of coded distributed computing techniques, including coded matrix multiplication and secure coded computing. To enhance the communication and networking capability of the platform, we developed learning-based control mechanisms to facilitate broadband long-range communication, and we also developed a software-defined radio (SDR)-based long-term evolution (LTE) communication system. To demonstrate the capabilities and potentials of the proposed platform, we have also investigated different applications, including multi-agent system control, visible/infrared-image-based object classification and detection, coded federated learning, UAV path/motion planning, UAV mobility modeling, and UAV traffic management. The results have been documented in over 50 publications in leading journals and conferences.

The PIs conducted major efforts in supporting the community by proving workshops, training opportunities, and field-test support. The project has directly supported about 20 research groups and researchers with hardware and/or software support. In addition, the team organized 7 tutorials and 1 workshop at major communication and UAV conferences and provided direct training to over 300 professionals. For those who cannot come to the face-to-face training, the project also produced two training video series on YouTube (12 videos in total) that are broadly accessible to guide the research community to build step by step the developed system, including the UAV platform and the communication/computing system. The software and hardware design are also available on the project website. In order to reach out to broader communities and promote the networked UAV research, the team also organized three student design competitions titled Networked Computing on the Edge at major conferences including IEEE ACM/TM and CPS IoT Weeks, participated by over 30 university teams, with collaborative organization effort with companies including MathWorks and Nvidia.

The project results in significant broader impacts. The proposed infrastructure opens up opportunities for CISE researchers to quickly develop and test solutions that address many new fundamental challenges in networked airborne computing, to significantly advance cross-cutting research development in computing, communication, control, and aerospace, and to produce broader civilian and economic impact related to multi-UAS applications. The project materials have been integrated into two courses at SDSU and one new course at UTA. At UTA, the project has funded 8 graduate students, 2 undergraduate students, and 2 postdocs, including the graduation of 3 Ph.D. students. At UNT, the project has funded 1 Ph.D. student and 1 master student. The project also played a pivotal role at UNT to create the Center of Integrated Intelligent Mobility Systems and to develop a $1.2M outdoor UAV test center. At SDSU, the project has funded 2 Ph.D. students and 3 undergraduate students. At UPRM, the project has funded 2 Ph.D. students and supported the research activities of a large number of underrepresented minority students. The team also conducted many outreach activities to support STEM education, by delivering talks on the project, offering lab tours, serving as faculty advisors for student clubs, hosting summer camps, and engaging community college and undergraduate students, especially those from underrepresented minority groups, into the project.
